title: E field of distribution - 90 and 270 degree arcs

content.question: Two different charged insulators with the same linear charge density are each in the shape of a thin, circular arc, as shown in the figure. The two insulators subtend different angles along circles of the same radius. One arc subtends an angle of <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>90</mn></math> degrees, and the other arc subtends an angle of <math alttext="270" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>270</mn></math> degrees, or <math alttext="90" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>90</mn></math> degrees less than a complete circle. Which of the following statements makes a correct claim about the electric field magnitudes at points <math alttext="O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></math> and <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, and provides evidence or reasoning that helps support the claim?

choices.label: The field magnitudes are different. The insulators subtend arcs of different angles.
The field magnitudes are different. The two insulators have a different total charge.
The field magnitudes are the same. The insulators have the same linear charge density and the same radius.
The field magnitudes are the same. Different portions of the <math alttext="270" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>270</mn></math>-degree insulator produce fields that cancel.

content.answer: The field magnitudes are the same. Different portions of the <math alttext="270" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>270</mn></math>-degree insulator produce fields that cancel.
